quests.description: Nether materials are all fairly dangerous to obtain, but with risk comes great reward! All these things have some fantastic uses, and also look great to decorate your abode with to show off your adventuring prowess!

tasks.longDescription: Okay so these aren't really Nether related, but decorative. You can make a Topiary grass and color it Red or Blue to decorate your lawns, cause sometimes you get lost Adventuring and forget to water your lawn and it dies and....where was I?
This works just like the regular Furnace, but being made of Netherrack, it burns for much longer, doubling the time a piece of Fuel lasts in it!

Soul Sand and Heat Sand can be cooked like regular Sand to get you some special Glass. Soul Glass can be walked through, but will slow you down. Heat Glass acts like Heat Sand and will hurt you if you aren't wearing boots!
The Obelisk uses the special properties of your world and lets you select where to respawn when you die, much like sleeping in a bed does.
This is just like a regular metal Hopper, except looks cooler!
Blaze Tracks of various kinds work just like regular minecart tracks...except they move you a LITTLE bit slower. Not sure why.

quests.name: Nether Ores
quests.description: The Nether is quite the dangerous place. And to an adventurer, danger equals reward! The hellish rock of the Nether holds valuable materials you can use! Each one is the equivilant of DOUBLE a normal piece of ore, and if you are an egghead and have some sorta machine to doubles your ore output, that means you DOUBLE it further! Right? Thats how math works I think!

quests.name: Simply Jetpacks
quests.description: When exploring and adventuring, invariably you are going to have to scale something pretty high. Big magic tower of doom, super tall ancient skyscraper, unbelievable floating sky island, etc etc. Well, there are plenty of ways to get up there, we in The Ferret Business have come up with magical and mundane ways of all sorts, but I like going simple. And whats more simple than strapping something to your back and rocketing to the sky?!

tasks.longDescription: Most jetpacks require this component. It keeps the burning cylinder attached to you!
Uh...I see you kind of got the idea, but you should probably give that to me...I don't think is safe. We Adventurers take risks, but not stupid ones afterall!

quests.name: Leadstone Jetpack
quests.description: Okay, now that I have that dangerous Spudnik away from you, lets make some ACTUAL jetpacks! There are a good number of jetpacks you can make, each one requiring a few thrusters made of some metals, some sort of energy conductor, a way to transform energy into thrust. You then toss it onto a metal frame with a leather strap with a battery on it, charge that baby up, and zoom to the clouds! I'll only ask you to make a basic Leadstone one, as the materials are fairly common, compared to the other jetpacks you can make.

tasks.longDescription: All jetpacks are worn on your chest. You'll have to turn on the jetpack with F (You will most likely have to rebind this to a different key). Double-tap jump to activate flight, then just land or double-tap to disable flight. You can also activate hover mode by hitting C, but this takes more energy when not on the ground. Hover Mode lets you decend slowly when not outright flying.

quests.name: Backpack Battery
quests.description: If flight isn't your thing (or you have some kind of fancy Magic jewelry to let you fly), you can instead replace some of the components with more ways to store and discharge RF Energy. When you activate a Capacitor Pack, it will charge powered armor you are wearing, as well as any item in your hand. Quite handy!

tasks.longDescription: Like the Jetpack, this is worn on your chest. To start charging your armor and held item, use the F key (or the key you rebound your Jetpack key to).

quests.name: Backpack Capacitor
quests.description: If flight isn't your thing (or you have some kind of fancy Magic jewelry to let you fly), you can instead replace some of the components with more ways to store and discharge RF Energy. When you activate a Capacitor Pack, it will charge powered armor you are wearing, as well as any item in your hand. Quite handy!

tasks.longDescription: Like the Jetpack, this is worn on your chest. To start charging your armor and held item, use the F key (or the key you rebound your Jetpack key to).

quests.name: Armored Jetpacks
quests.description: The bad thing is, Simple Jetpacks are worn on your back, and with the heavy straps and controls, you can't really wear armor with them. Thats okay, though, because you can MAKE armor for your jetpack! Each jetpack can be equipped with a specific type of armor, just hold the jetpack in your hands and have the proper armor plating in your inventory, and Sneak + Right Click the jetpack to install the armor on it.

quests.name: A Unique Thruster
quests.description: Since we're not really using a giant canister of volatile chemicals as our propulsion system, we can do some fancy things with the exhaust. By combining these custom components, you can change what the thruster flames look like!

tasks.longDescription: This one will reset your thruster flames to normal.
Ride the Rainbow!
Remove the fire effect and leave it as just smoke with this.
You can go stealth mode with this and remove the thruster effect entirely!

quests.name: MATERIAL - WRIGGLING TENTACLE
quests.description: Material :  Wriggling Tentacle          Amount :   20                       Targets : Squids, Ghasts, or any         creature with a whip-like               appendage                    Bounty :   1 Bag of Coins

quests.name: MATERIAL - MYSTICAL POWDER
quests.description: Material :  Mystical Powder             Amount :   20                       Targets : Witches, Demons, and            other Magical Entities           Bounty :   1 Bag of Coins

quests.name: MATERIAL -  CREEPY FLESH
quests.description: Material :  Creepy Flesh          Amount :   20                       Targets : Endermen or any                creature with strange skin        Bounty :   1 Bag of Coins

quests.name: A Fashionable Greeting
quests.description: Hm hm hmmm, Bitsy passed on to me that an assistant is stuck in another world, possibly alone and...well, they could use all the help they can get! I take it that is you? Of course it is, it has your name right here on my QUEST Tablet : Bandit, Very Lost Assistant. Don't worry, it's not saying you don't know anything, just the name we give Assistants who are kind of...unretrievable. You aren't exactly the FIRST assistant The Ferret Business has teleported out of reach. But fret not my fine ferret, with my help you'll be putting your own mark on that world yet! In fact, why don't you make a sign so you can proclaim it yours?

tasks.longDescription: By crouching when you place a sign, you can lay it flat on the front of a chest, flat on the ground, or even flat on the ceiling!

quests.name: Bibliocraft
quests.description: A house is not a home unless it has that...personal...touch, I say. Whether its a shelf full of treasured knicknacks, a favorite picture on the wall, or just simply a desk to call your own and a bookshelf full of novels. To make your house a home, I know of a lot of different bits of furniture and decorations that look spectacular. Not only that, most everthing is functional in some way as well! Now to start, lets make this cute little desk bell. Its useful if you plan on running a hotel desk or a shop counter, otherwise its just a cute adornment.

tasks.longDescription: You can ding the bell by Right Clicking it, or by sending a Redstone Signal to it!

quests.name: A Grand Timepiece
quests.description: A digital clock is all well and good, easy to read at a glance, but it doesn't have much...well, style, does it? Sure sure, fancy fonts and decorative frames are possible, but sometimes tried and true classics give the best style to a situation! The Grandfather clock is elegant and really stands out in a room. The clock face shows you the local time, while the pendulum (the little swinging thing) is synced to us here in The Ferret Business, ticks every Real second.

tasks.longDescription: You can make it twice as tall by stacking one on top of another, then Sneak + Right Clicking each Clock with a Screwgun or Hand Drill.

quests.name: No Writer's Block
quests.description: Given that you are kind of stuck in that world for a while, I bet you have a ton of things to write, right? Notes maybe, instructions to yourself or other assistants you may have found. Or heck, books, entire novels just swimming in your head, and now the time to write them...well, when you aren't clawing and scraping about to survive. I have a lot of beautiful and useful furniture you can make use of!

tasks.longDescription: Even in this age of Computers, there is something lovely about an old Typewriter. You can place a pile of papers into it, and then tap away at the front to type up a novel! Or, you can hire a ghostwriter! Give some creature or animal a name with a Nametag, then plop them in front of the typewriter! Just note that...what they write maaay not be all that legible...

By combining the functions of a Bookcase and a Crafting Table, you can not only save space, but also work better! With a normal Book, you can write a recipe to it on this, then place it onto the built in Shelf (or any book for that matter!)

The Typesetting Table allows you to copy Signed Books onto Printing Plates, to make a copy of later. Hold the book and right click it onto the lower left spot on top of the table. You can then Sneak + Right Click it to turn it blue and save it. Hold and Right Click a Printing Press Chase into the spot near the back of the tabletop, then right click the gray areas to the left or right of the Chase. You can select a saved book here, and then apply a Redstone Signal to the Typesetting Table to copy the book to the Chase.

The Chase you just made can be taken to this Printing Press. Right Click it onto the center area to put it in, then Right Click some Ink Sacs near it to apply Ink to the Press. Take a regular Book (not a Book and Quill or a written Book), and Right Click it onto the lower left countertop to place it there. When all three items are in the Printing Press, it will start working to make a copy of the book. When the book turns Blue, you can pick it up!

quests.name: Elegant Display
quests.description: Nothing makes better decor than showing off your curios. Simple things like a pretty stone, to complicated things like a Nether Star, can be shown off equally well in the right circumstances. I have a wide array of shelves and ways to show off your collections.

tasks.longDescription: These Bookcases are much more elegant than your vanilla Bookshelf. You can store up to 16 different books on this by Right Clicking a book onto it to place it in that spot, and later grab it off by Sneak + Right Clicking the book with an empty hand. For Enchanting purposes, every 8 books on a Bookcase counts as a single Bookshelf.
Each Shelf can hold up to 4 stacks of items. Place them on the shelf by Right Clicking one of the four spots, and you can remove the item again by just Right Clicking it.
You can Right Click almost any tool to place it up on this Rack. Right Click it again to remove it.

If you are a wiz Alchemist, you probably have a big pile of Potions about. These Shelves are great for storing and displaying them. Each one can hold 12 Potions for you! Simply place them or remove them with a Right Click.

If you have a unique, single special item you'd like to display, why not make a Case just for it? These fancy cases can be opened by Sneak + Right Clicking them with an empty hand, then the item placed inside. Sneak + Right Click again to close the case and secure the display.

Sometimes old school goodness can really improve a room. If you have old Jukebox Music Discs, you can place them in this Disc Rack to display them nicely. You can place these on the floor, the wall, or even the ceiling, and rotate them around by holding a Screwgun or Hand Drill and Sneak + Right Clicking.
Dinnerware is a fancy, timeless thing to add to any dining room. These Plates are large enough to hold three different food items, and can be eaten off of directly.

This Cookie Jar should be a staple in all kitchens. It's a special one, in that any item put into it will show up as a Cookie on the outside, making it a fantastic place to hide something. It even emits a Redstone signal when the jar is opened, to make a trap to catch Cookie thieves!

quests.name: Painted Dreams
quests.description: Wooden walls, stone walls, wallpaper, all of it is nice but tends to be kind of monotonous in large rooms, no? I like to break up large, empty expanses of walls with Paintings! They come in lots of sizes, with a wide range of designs you can choose from!

tasks.longDescription: You'll need a proper canvas to start with, something to  print the design onto.

Take your Painting Canvas and place it into this Press. You can choose from a nice selection of Paintings to print onto it. You can't place this directly on the wall yet, you'll need to make a frame for it.

There are a bunch of different ways to frame your Paintings on the wall. You can make a  Borderless one so it looks like a poster, or you can make varying style of frames to place the Painting into. I'll only ask you to make two of them, though, don't worry!
Know what else looks fantastic on a wall? A map, of course! You can use these Map Frames much like the Painting Frames, but they have the added bonus of being useable with a few fantastic tools...

When you have a map up on a Map Frame, you can use the Drafting Compas to mark locations on it. With the Waypoint Compass, you can use it on a waypoint you marked with the Drafting Compass, or Sneak + Right Click it to enter coordinates and the Compass will point towards it.

quests.name: Warrior's Pride
quests.description: To a fighter, a lot of his arms and armor are more about helping him survive than they are about looks...but thats perfect, as they tend to LOOK good as well. Symmetrical armor, a lot of layers, textures, all of it combined look fantastic. You can proudly show off your gear with these stands.

tasks.longDescription: You can display various outfits on this stand. Right clicking will open up an interface where you can place the armor, but if you Sneak + Right Click instead, you'll swap whatever you are wearing (even if its nothing!) with the armor piece you click!
You can place almost any sword into this pedastal to display it. When it is holding a sword, it emits a Redstone Signal, which is great for creating showy light effects on cue.

quests.name: Informational Fancy
quests.description: Not my usual way to spruce up a place, but using Signs and Labels can be quite helpful, and who says these things can't also LOOK nice as well? Made with the various types of wood, you can get these to fit into any decorative theme, I feel.

tasks.longDescription: A sign on a chest tends to get in the way when you are labeling things. This little label is quite handy, as it doesn't cover the front of the Chest. Open the interface by Right Clicking it with an empty hand.

The Fancy Sign is wonderful, you can customize the text on it in various ways, and even display a couple items on it! Sneak + Right Click it with an empty hand to open up the interface, which explains everything.

quests.name: A Hip Style
quests.description: Glasses...well, they tend to fade in and out of style, really. Sometimes they are out of style and you should probably wear contacts, other times the old school Monocole is best. For us, Glasses are ALWAYS in, as they are quite helpful in pointing out small things with many of these decorative things I'm showing you.

tasks.longDescription: When worn, Glasses, Tinted Glasses, and Monocoles will pop up text of any item in a Bibliocraft block, such as the name of a Book in a Bookcase, what Potion on a Potion Shelf, etc.
You can give a stylish tint to your Reading Glasses quite easily.
You can also make a Monocole for a more high-brow look.
What better way to show your style than by making something unique? You'll need a Framing Saw to start with, then you can combine it with any kind of Plank to make Framing Boards and Sheets.

You can use Framing Sheets in place of Wood Planks and Framing Panels in place of Slabs in a recipe to make a Framed version of the furniture. You can then place it into a Furniture Paneler, and design it with almost any Solid Block texture.

quests.name: Special Editions
quests.description: Books contain so much knowledge. They can also contain much, much more! Our bookshelves can be filled with endless storybooks and instruction manuals, but there are a couple of very special books we can fill them with as well, each one doing something different.

tasks.longDescription: For when a regular Book isn't big enough or fancy enough, the Big Writing Book lets you have multiple chapters, fancy text, and much more!
The Slotted Book looks like a signed book and can be renamed. Only instead of a story, it contains a single item slot within it.

When placed in a Bookcase, this book emits a Redstone Signal at the strength of the slot its put in. If put in the upper left, it emits no signal, but the lower right slot emits full strength. Don't forget you can rename this in an Anvil!

If you like drawing maps while exploring, you eventually come to the point where you are holding more maps than actual tools...Thats where the Atlas comes in! It can hold, display, organize, and even draw up new maps for you! You can also enchant the Atlas, and if you die, you'll reappear with an Eternal Compass that will guide you back to your stuff!

quests.name: Enlightened
quests.description: Being able to see in the dark is quite useful, and we can't all wear fancy night vision goggles. They aren't very stylish anyways. What IS stylish, though, are metal Lamps, especially in Gold! All of these lamps look slightly different whether you place them on the floor, the wall, or the ceiling. They can also be colored various colors with a bit of dye!

tasks.longDescription: You can make the lamps out of either Iron or Gold.
You can make the lantern out of either Iron or Gold.

quests.name: Handy Tools
quests.description: Decorating isn't all just pointing and color matching, a lot of it requires special tools. Does this room have enough space for a bed? Did we get all the furniture we wanted? And so on and so on. All these tools I use regularly and should be quite helpful to you as well!

tasks.longDescription: The Tape Measure helps you measure distances between two points. Right Click it onto the first block, then on the second block to see how far the two are from each other. You can also rotate items on tables with this by Right Clicking it onto one of the sides of the table.
The Clipboard allows you to make multiple lists and check them off. Handy when you have a big project going.

The Screw Gun and Hand Drill do the same things. They can rotate most Bibliocraft and Vanilla blocks when Sneak + Right Clicking. Many Bibliocraft blocks can also be changed just by Right Clicking them with one of these tools.

Not sure how deep that ocean is, or how far to the ground that jump is? Break out a Plumb Line and find out! Stand right in front of the drop you want to measure the depth of and Right Click with this item. It'll tell you how far down the next solid block is.

quests.name: Your Table Awaits
quests.description: Standing, its all well and good, but after a while its quite tiring. Especially if you are trying to do something like...say eat dinner or read a book or write a book or...well, lots of things! Thankfully you have plenty of options for both sitting and working, from desks and tables to chairs and thrones. A wide range of styles and options to choose from!

tasks.longDescription: Tables are handy for placing items on by simply Right Clicking them onto the table. You can then rotate them by Right Clicking a Tape Measure on any side of the table. You can also add a tablecloth by right clicking the top with a Carpet, or add a rug by Right Clicking the side of the table with the Carpet. You can remove a tablecloth by Right Clicking the top with a Screwgun or Handsaw, and a Rug by Sneak + Right Clicking the side of the Table with a Screwgun or Handsaw.

You can place Books down on this desk by Right Clicking them either on the back left or right corners to stack them, or the center to place an open book. You can grab a book by Sneak + Right Clicking with an empty hand. A Typewriter set on the desk will automatically stack finished Books onto one of the two stacks.

You can upholster these seats by Right Clicking it with a colored Carpet. You can connect multiple seats together by holding a Screwgun or Hand Drill and Sneak + Right Clicking each one you want to connect together. Repeat the process to disconnect them.

There is a wide array of of options when you want to add a back to your Seats. You can rotate which way the back is facing by Sneak + Right Clicking the legs of the Seat with a Hand Drill or Screwgun. You can remove the Seat Back and the Upholstery by Sneak + Right Clicking the top of the Seat.

quests.name: Red String Theory
quests.description: Ever heard of String Theory? Some of the other research labs have talked about it in the lunch area a few times and it got us thinking of possibilities. After some research and testing, we've come up with something we like to call Red String Theory.                                Not just Theory, really, we've actually made string. Thats red. And works amazingly! You can create devices with it that can connect to something up to eight meters away from one of the block's faces (So, straight from any of a block's six sides). Each Red String Device connects to a different kind of block or device, and does something different, and each Device can only bind to one thing at a time.                                You can literally see the Red String connection by holdinging your Wand of the Forest! Once bound, any blocks can be placed between the two without breaking the String.

tasks.longDescription: The Red String Container will bind to any inventory it finds. You can then insert items into the Red String Container with a Hopper or other inserting device, and the items will instead be inserted into the inventory.

The Red String Dispenser can bind to either a Dispenser or a Dropper. It acts much like the Red String Container, any item inserted into the Red String Dispenser will instead be placed in the bound block, but with the addition of a Redstone Signal on the Red String Dispenser will cause the bound block to activate.
The Red String Nutrifier can bind to any block that can be fertilized with Bonemeal. Fertilizing the Red String Nutrifier will instead fertilize the bound block.

The Red String Comparator can bind to anything that can be read by a Comparator, like Containers, Mana Pools, etc. Then placing a Comparator next to the Red String Comparator, facing out, it will emit a Redstone Signal at the proper strength, as if the Comparator was right next to the bound block.

The Red String Spoofer can bind to any Flower and even some Mushrooms. You can then place any flower with an effect on top of the Red String Spoofer. The bound flower or mushroom will no longer function as itself, it will instead act exactly like the Flower on top of the Red String Spoofer.
The Red String Interceptor can be bound to any complex block, like a Furnace or a machine. When you or an assistant Right Clicks that block, the Interceptor will emit a Redstone Pulse.

quests.name: MATERIAL - DOWNY FEATHER
quests.description: Material :  Downy Feather              Amount :   20                       Targets : Any bird-like creature     Bounty :   1 Bag of Coins

quests.name: MATERIAL - TINGED LEAF
quests.description: Material :  Tinged Leaf              Amount :   20                       Targets : Any plant-based                 creature                             Bounty :   1 Bag of Coins

quests.name: MATERIAL - HIDE SAMPLE
quests.description: Material :  Hide Sample              Amount :   20                       Targets : Any creature with little        to no fur                      Bounty :   1 Bag of Coins

quests.name: MATERIAL - FUR TUFT
quests.description: Material :  Fur Tuft              Amount :   20                       Targets : Any creature with large        amounts of fur              Bounty :   1 Bag of Coins

quests.name: High Technology
quests.description: There are a few factory engineers I'd like to get you in contact with here. They are sort of a team, but work on different aspects of a factory and automation line. Sending one of them a few special materials should garner their attention!

tasks.longDescription: Currently, only half of the quests in this questline are complete.

quests.name: Compact Machines
quests.description: What every mechanic, good or bad, realizes really quickly is...you just don't have the space for all your tools and machines! Sure, you can get a bigger shop, a second shop, a fifth shop, an aircraft hangar, an entire apartment building even, but it still just won't be enough space! Plus, if you get yourself a huge space, you still have to wire everything up, and worry about zoning permits and....where was I?       Oh, right! Well, we like to employ something we call Meek's Law : The potential effectiveness of any factory or machine increases as its footprint decreases. Which means....the smaller you make it, the more efficient it can become. And what better way to make something super effecient than by shrinking them down!

tasks.longDescription: These two are the basis of making super Compact Machines. They are kind of like Capacitors or Coils, they don't really do much until you put them into a machine.

quests.name: MineFactory Reloaded
quests.description: You're here, great! Like I said, my name is Meeka. My twin brother and I are the head factory engineers here at The Ferret Business. While he focuses smaller, more powerful systems, I focus on getting things moving like clockwork.     Now, I hear talk about how your world's materials are all infused with Magic, and I've been doing some tinkering on my own with samples and...I'm already loving what I've found! I think we can come up with a better, more efficient factory.            First though, you'll need to gather some materials and the basic components...

tasks.longDescription: Bouncy Bouncy, who doesn't like rubber? Good cushion, good insulator, fun material! Scans show you have Rubber Trees around. Multiple types, in fact, but the one I know of has sort of an orangish bark and bright green leaves. Chop it down and you'll get some Raw Rubber, which you can Smelt down into Rubber Bars.

Rubber is good for insulating cables, but what we'll be using it for is making plastic. Smelt Rubber Bars down to refine them into Raw Plastic, and then you can combine four bars worth into  Plastic Sheets.

The Factory Machine Block is the heart of almost every MFR machine. Usually, a machine can only be powered with RF Energy...but the magical nature of your materials, it seems to be able to be powered by EU and MJ as well.                       Likewise, these Pipes seem to be special. When you apply a Redstone Signal to them, they can pull liquid out of a machine or tank, but when they are made of material from your world, they don't seem to melt when pumping, say...Lava. Or Molten Metal. That is amazing!

This Sledgehammer can be used to rotate MFR and other machines. A strange thing, when you are holding it, you can see the range of MFR machines...must be a magical link between all the Plastic used...

quests.name: Progressive Automation
quests.description: There are a lot of seemingly simple tasks you need to do to survive out there, isn't there? My brother and I were talking over this, and we feel the best way to help you is to teach you one of the easiest series of automations you can do. The best thing about these machines is you can Progressively upgrade them to work bigger areas and faster!

tasks.longDescription: All of these machines take some sort of Fuel to power. Sometimes, though, a large chunk of Coal is a waste to use for a single machine, so you can break it down into a Fuel Pellet to be more efficient.
You can customize your Automation machines using this wrench. By Sneak + Right Clicking it into the air, you can change modes, then Right Click a side of the machine to change what it does.

quests.name: Hearty Meals
quests.description: [[INCOMPLETE QUESTLINE]]                                                          You can submit materials to help this research branch for the future, and immediately gain access to its questline when it becomes available.

quests.name: Electronic Mind
quests.description: [[INCOMPLETE QUESTLINE]]                                                          You can submit materials to help this research branch for the future, and immediately gain access to its questline when it becomes available.

quests.name: Pressurised Air
quests.description: [[INCOMPLETE QUESTLINE]]                                                          You can submit materials to help this research branch for the future, and immediately gain access to its questline when it becomes available.

quests.name: Steve the Inventor
quests.description: [[INCOMPLETE QUESTLINE]]                                                          You can submit materials to help this research branch for the future, and immediately gain access to its questline when it becomes available.

quests.name: Crystal Storage
quests.description: [[INCOMPLETE QUESTLINE]]                                                          You can submit materials to help this research branch for the future, and immediately gain access to its questline when it becomes available.

quests.name: Grim Power
quests.description: [[INCOMPLETE QUESTLINE]]                                                          You can submit materials to help this research branch for the future, and immediately gain access to its questline when it becomes available.

quests.name: Network Tools
quests.description: [[INCOMPLETE QUESTLINE]]                                                          You can submit materials to help this research branch for the future, and immediately gain access to its questline when it becomes available.

quests.name: Creature Feature
quests.description: You may have noticed, if you've been using your Wyvern weapons, that very rarely, a tiny version of a creature you slaughter will pop out of their corpse.                          This, we've found, is a miniature version of that creature's Soul. The simplest thing you can do with this Soul is to Shift + Right Click it on the ground to summon another of that creature, but this consumes the soul.                                       Thanks to some study by the draconic researchers here, we've discovered you can use a Draconic Core on any Mob Spawner in your world to 'stabilize it', enabling you to move it around.                           You can then place it and Right Click a Mob Soul onto it to have that Stabilized Mob Spawner start spawning that creature. Various items will improve the Mob Spawner when you Right Click them onto it :        Wyvern Core : Tier 2 Upgrade        Awakened Core : Tier 3 Upgrade      Nether Star : Removes requiring a player within 16 blocks.                  Notch Apple : Removes spawning restrictions (light, etc)

tasks.longDescription: To obtain a Stabilized Spawner, Right Click a Draconic Core on any Mob Spawner in the world. You can then break it with your Draconic tools and move it around.

By killing creatures with Draconic weaponry, you can rarely obtain a Mob Soul. Right Clicking it into a Stabilized Mob Spawner will cause it to spawn that creature.         Note that when you break a Stabilized Spawner, you will get back all upgrades EXCEPT the Mob Soul.

The Mob Grinder is a special machine we've come up with that will kill creatures in a 7x7 area in front of it.                                     It can be powered with normal furnace Fuel, or with RF Energy.

quests.name: Power of the Stars
quests.description: I have Invented what I feel is one of the most powerful Generators to date! After you've shown me that Unstable Block, I got some ideas while I was working on improving the Generators even more. By using the immense potential energy of a Nether Star, with the logic bending properties of Unstable material, I've come up with this super Generator! I'm not sure any energy pipes I know of can transfer this much energy at once....

tasks.longDescription: Be careful! Once it starts to Generate power, it will damage any living or unliving creature within 10 blocks of it!

quests.name: Obelisk, Cooperate!
quests.description: We now have a large pile of specialized crystals we can use, but we need a special sort of machine to utilize them, and I believe we have come up with just the thing. Taking some notes from the occult branches of The Business, we've come up with a machine version of an Obelisk, or totem, which can do a variety of things, depending on which crystal or item you construct the Obelisk with.

tasks.longDescription: Attractor Obelisks draw creatures nearby to it, if they match one of the Soul's stored inside the Obelisk.
When supplied with power and the appropriate Catalyst, this Obelisk can change the weather for you.

Using one of the special Endermen logic processors, we can make a device that will allow you to 'dissuade' creature from appearing close to it, as long as you have placed a Vial containing a similar soul into the Obelisk.
Allows you to give or take Experience, and pump it in liquid form out (or into) the Obelisk.

quests.name: Bigger, Better, Faster
quests.description: So lately I've been tinkering with ways of making your Ender Quarry even better. Since it uses some of the Magic of the Endermen, we can't really use the same conventional means as other Quarries or machines to upgrade them. I have, however, Invented a way to augment the Ender Quarry! These devices need to be placed so that they touch the Ender Quarry itself to enhance it. Each one does something different, and some cause a bigger power draw than others.

tasks.longDescription: This is the base you'll build all Upgrades on.
Normally, the Ender Quarry only grabs things that are not Dirt or Stone and replaces them with Dirt. This upgrade will have the Ender Quarry grab everything without replacing it.
This Upgrade will have the Quarry pick up blocks whole, instead of breaking them. You'll get Redstone Ore instead of it breaking down into Redstone Dust, for example.

Each of these Upgrades improves the chance of extra drops when the Quarry mines something that breaks into other components (For example, you may get 5 or more Redstone Dust per Ore instead of the normal 4).
These Upgrades will enhance the speed the Quarry works.
This Upgrade adds the Ender Pump to the Quarry, enabling it to grab Liquid as well as long as it has a valid pipe or tank to pump it through.

quests.name: Carpenter's Blocks
quests.description: You know, in architecture, the common 'style' has been squares. Right angles. Rectangles. Anything with a 90 degree angle. Steps are just small stacks of squares. Even 'round' buildings are made with columns of square blocks, just arranged in a circle. Practical, but...boring. I think we can add a little pizzazz to any building just by embracing the odd angle.

tasks.longDescription: It all starts...with a square. Yes, I know, I talk about angles and slopes, but it all stems from the core structure of a Carpenter's Block.

quests.name: A Carpenter's Tools
quests.description: Now, those Carpenter's Blocks I showed you how to make are special. You can Right Click any other solid block onto it to apply it as a Cover. Carpenter's Blocks, and many other blocks you can make WITH Carpenter's Blocks, like Carpenter's Stairs, have Side Covers, which can be placed on top of normal covers. Each "side" that can have a cover can be customized with a different block, and further customized with a chiseled texture if you Right Click a Carpenter's Chisel on it. You can remove any Cover on a block by Sneak + Right Clicking the Cover with a Carpenter's Hammer.

tasks.longDescription: The Hammer is useful not just for removing Covers, but for customizing almost any Carpenter's Block. By Right Clicking the Hammer on a block, you can cycle through its 'styles'. You can then rotate the block around by Left Clicking on the block with the Hammer.
Want a design to POP more with some texture? Take out your Carpenter's Chisel and Left or Right Click on a Carpenter's Block that has a Cover on it.

quests.name: More Construction Options
quests.description: Now, Carpenter's Blocks can be knocked into half slabs with a hammer, but that can bring your designs only so far, you know? You have a variety of stairs and slops you can use as well! Not only that, you can put an Overlay on many of these blocks! Overlays add another layer of design to your builds, just Sneak + Right Click one of these items onto the block to add it as an Overlay.                                         Seed for Grass                          Snowball for Snow                       Vine for Vine                              String for Web                            Wheat for Hay                            Mushroom for Mycellium

tasks.longDescription: Stairs and Slopes will automatically try to orient themselves if you Right Click them against the face of a Carpenter's Block. If this orients them oddly, you can hold Sneak when Right Clicking to prevent this.

Slopes have a wide variety of designs. You can cycle through them after placing them with a Hammer like usual, but you can also hold them in your hand, hold Sneak and use your Mouse Wheel to cycle through them.

Want finer control of the slopes? Place down some of these Collapsible Blocks and Right Click a corner or quadrant to lower it, or Left Click to raise it. It'll try to keep an even transition between blocks, but you can hold Sneak when raising or lowering a block to ignore this ability.

Carpenter's Barriers will automatically create posts at intersections and corners, and you can force a post connection by Left Clicking the barrier with your Carpenter's Hammer. You can cycle through fence styles by Right Clicking with your Hammer, but the normal Fence style can have the board depth changed by Sneak + Right Clicking with your hammer.

quests.name: Redeem Gold Chit
quests.description: Fulfilling Contracts succesfully earns you Trader Chits. By combining two of the same value, you get a larger chit.                 The larger the chit you redeem, the more value it has. Four Bronze[8] chits are worth less than a single Silver[32] chit. Four Silver[32] chits are worth less than a single Thaumium[128] chit, and so on.

quests.name: Redeem Bronze Chit
quests.description: Fulfilling Contracts succesfully earns you Trader Chits. By combining two of the same value, you get a larger chit.                 The larger the chit you redeem, the more value it has. Four Bronze[8] chits are worth less than a single Silver[32] chit. Four Silver[32] chits are worth less than a single Thaumium[128] chit, and so on.

quests.name: Corporea Item Logistics
quests.description: Our prior research into these little bundles of life we made called Sparks intrigued some of the other Research branches here in the Business. A few of them have been working with us and the Elves to come up with something new and innovative with them.                          With the poweful nature of both Elven materials and Ender Air, instead of transporting Mana between each Spark, we are able to create a network of Sparks that can move whole items between inventories! You will need a Master Corporea Spark and a bunch of Corporea Sparks for each network, plus a way to Interface with them to make requests.

tasks.description: Did You Make a Spark Yet?
tasks.longDescription: If you haven't, you'll need to make a bunch of them!

Corporea Sparks can be placed on top of any inventory, similar to how Sparks are placed on top of Mana Pools. They can connect to other Corporea Sparks within 8 blocks, creating a network (if there is also a Master Corporea Spark). Each Corporea Spark has access to the inventory directly below it.

To create a Corporea Network, you must have one Master Corporea Spark. Each Network is seperated by a color, which you can see floating around the Corporea Sparks. You can change the network a Corporea Spark is on by Right Clicking some Floral Powder onto the spark. Note that the inventory a Master Spark is on cannot have its items pulled by normal Sparks.

The Corporea Funnel can connect to any Corporea Network via placing a Corporea Spark atop it. By placing Item Frames on each side of the Funnel, it will pull any items placed into these Frames from the network and put them into an inventory one to two blocks below it. It will do this one item at a time, and at random between the Item Frames. You can rotate the item in the frame to have it pull multiples of that item at once.

To pull items out of your Corporea Network, you'll need an Index. By placing this down and connecting it to a Corporea Spark Network like any other Inventory, you can stand next to it and say what you want. It will search all connected inventories and give you the item. You can preceed the request with a number to get that many, or say "this" to get more of the item you are holding in your hand. You can also type count (like count iron bar) to see how many are in the network.

The Corporea Intercepter listens to your Corporea Requests, and will output a Redstone Signal if a request is not fulfilled. To do this, it must have at least one Item Frame with an item on the Intercepter, and if a request for said item cannot be completed, it will emit the Redstone Signal. This can be used to activate machines or other things.

The Corporea Crystal Cube allows you to easily see the amount of an item in your Network. Place it down and attach it to a network with a Corporea Spark. Right Click any block or item onto the Spark to have it track that item. You can then Left Click to request 1 of that item, or Sneak + Left Click to request an entire stack.

Placing the Retainer next to an Interceptor enables to to remember the last request sent to the network, and repeat it if a Redstone Signal hits it.                      This is especially useful for Automation purposes, as crafting can be activated by the Interceptor, then the request repeated after it is done.

quests.name: Malisis' Doors
quests.description: Plain wood and metal doors are so...plain. And boring. We have so many stylish options for walls, ceilings, floors, furniture, why not doors as well? See, I know of a great designer known as M, who I've been talking with behind the scenes, and he's shown me some fantastic designs and given me great tips and tricks for designing eye catching doors!

tasks.longDescription: The first thing he showed me was a fantastic way to open doors without ever having to leave fingerprints on them! This can be placed on a wall next to a door, or connected to Redstone that leads to the door. When you or an assistant walks up to it, it'll send a Redstone signal, which will open the door upon your approach!

quests.name: Classical Doorways
quests.description: As much as I posture about being eye catching and unique, there still is a place for old school, reliable designs, with perhaps a little twist. As long as they fit the design of the rest of the building, that is. It'd be quite silly to have an old wooden door be the way into a high-tech laboratory, after all!

tasks.longDescription: These work just like their normal wood and iron counterparts, but instead of rotating on a hinge, they slide into the walll next to them!
These elegant doors are much like the sliding ones, except they slide open and close much slower.
Sometimes a solid door just isn't necessary. Fabric itself can lend a nice touch, giving a bit of privacy as well as style to a room.

quests.name: Specialty Doors
quests.description: Making lovely, unique doors for a domicile is one thing, but why don't we make some nice doors for a business or the like as well? If your work is as comfortable as your home, you work harder and longer and are more relaxed! Well, usually I would think.

tasks.longDescription: The Garage Door can be any size, as long as all the pieces are facing the same way. When you apply a Redstone Signal to any part of it, the entire door will slide upward as a single unit.
The Factory Door opens by splitting in the center and sliding both up and down.
The Laboratory Door slides upward when opened. It does not function as a double door.
The Jail Door opens by sliding sideways. It can also only be opened by a Redstone Signal.

quests.name: A Little Old, A Little New
quests.description: There's something to be said about really atmospheric builds. Using modern materials to build some sort of themed creation, making the outside of your house look like a submarine or a lighthouse or some super futuristic fortress. Using a normal door just wouldn't cut it for these.

tasks.longDescription: This rustic doorway comes complete with its own rusty ladders! It takes a lot of space, though, as you need room for the giant door to open. If you place it on the top half of a block side, it'll open upwards.
If you need to extend the ladder of the Rusty Hatch, or just want a more atmospheric ladder, you can make more Rusty Ladders.

The Forcefield Controller can make a Forcefield doorway of nearly any size (It has a limit of about 100 blocks). Right Click it on the side of the first block, then on the second block you want to create the Forcefield between. You can then turn the forcefield on and off with the Controller. Sneak + Right Click the Controller on the Forcefield to remove it instead.

quests.name: Truely Your Own
quests.description: There are a lot of different styles of doors for you to choose from, but sometimes none of them fit your decor just right. With the Door Factory, you can mix blocks together to make a custom door, selecting the material for the frame and the door itself. You can also choose how it opens, what sounds it makes, and more! Perhaps, though, you also want to customize your blocks? With the Block Mixer, you can blend two blocks together.  With both of these, you can use a Bucket of Water or a Bucket of Lava to have a 'flowing' texture of that liquid. You can also use an Ender Pearl to show a swirling Portal.

tasks.longDescription: On top of the other options, you can use a Flint and Steel to have a fire effect on the door as well.
When mixing blocks, if the block emits light, the custom block will too. Mixing in a Redstone Block will have it emit redstone. Non-opaque blocks like glass will make the block see-through.

quests.name: Here and Gone Again
quests.description: Sometimes, you want a door that's just different. Whether its a heavy solid door flush with the rest of the wall, or a door that looks just like the wall itself, hiding your entrance so only you know where it is, you have a lot of options with Vanishing Frames! Once placed, you can Right Click any block onto the Vanishing Frame to copy its looks. When a Redstone Signal is applied to one, it will propogate the signal to all connected Vanishing Frames, though in different ways depending on what type of Vanishing Frame you've got.

tasks.longDescription: The Wooden Vanishing Frame will transmit the Redstone Signal to neighboring frames of all types.
Iron will only propogate the Redstone Signal to other Vanishing Frames that are copying the same block.

Gold Vanishing Frames are like Iron, but will only propogate the signal to frames with the same Block and Metadata. This means If you activate one that looks like White Wool, it won't send the signal to one that looks like Green Wool.
Diamond Vanishing Frames let you customize all these behaviours, even include a delay before it propogates the Redstone Signal!

quests.name: Tails
quests.description: You know, sometimes its not just your home you can customize. What about yourself? Well, with the QUEST Tablet, you can customize yourself with a spiffy, fluffy tail! Or some cute wings or ears! Just hit ESC for the main menu, and at the bottom is a button to customize your look! Choose from a wide variety of tails, wings, and ears, color them to your liking, and even save them as an outfit!

quests.name: Chisel 2
quests.description: Take a simple piece of Stone...or is it so simple? There are so many different things you can do to and with a piece of Stone. You can arrange it in various ways. You can paint it various colors. You can shape it. You can also...Chisel it. With a simple Chisel and an eye for decoration, you can turn lots of simple, many times boring, materials into spectacular, eye catching fancies! All you need is your Chisel and a stack of materials!

tasks.longDescription: ((Search for Chisel from Chisel 2 in NEI))                                   Right Click your Chisel to get the Inteface. You can put a wide variety of blocks in the left side, to see what you can turn them into in the right. If you Chisel a block and place it back into the left slow, you can close the Interface and then Left Click the same type of block in the world to change it to that design!

quests.name: A Custom Home
quests.description: There are a lot of things you can do to spruce up both the inside and outside of your home. Unique carpets, unique walls, unique ceilings! Even make the gifts you give unique!

tasks.longDescription: Thread some String in Wool to make Carpet. The outside edges of placed Carpet will have a different design than the center.
You can combine two Carpet to make a Floor Carpet, also known as a Rug.
You can give Stained Clay walls a bit of a textured touch to them by adding Wool.
By surrounding a wooden Stick with Paper, you can get this thin, elegant wall material.
By combining a handful of the Paper Walls, you can make it into a box, widening your design choices.

quests.name: Naturally Custom
quests.description: There are plenty of naturally created materials you can harvest and Chisel, these three being some of the more interesting! They are not as common as Stone is, but can be found underground all the same.

tasks.description: And A Sight For Sore Eyes!

quests.name: Tossable Toys
quests.description: There's a few ways you can spruce up a build that doesn't involve taking your Chisel to it. These three 'toys' are quite different from each other, but be careful with them all the same!

tasks.longDescription: Bottling some Quartz in Glass gets you a Cloud in a Bottle. You can Right click it to throw it, and where it hits spawns a big, fluffy cloud! It is the only way to get special Cloud blocks to Chisel.
By wrapping Vines and Sticks together, you get a Ball of Moss. When Right Clicked to throw it, any Cobblestone the splash hits will be covered in Moss.
Combining a Stone Pickaxe and Shovel and putting them in a Glass Bottle (don't ask how!), you get something you can throw that will smash Stone to Cobble, Cobble to Gravel, and Gravel to Sand.

quests.name: A Custom Fantasy
quests.description: What if I told you that you could Chisel your way to a more fantastical life? Well, you can at least Chisel yourself a nice Fantasy setting. Your imagination is the limit with all these designs you can just picture being from stalwart dwarves, elegant elves, and mad overlords.

tasks.longDescription: Surrounding a Gold Nugget with Stone gets you this white marble and gold inlaid block. great for princely castles.
If your designs are less flashy and more spiritual, look no further than the Temple Block, obtainable by surrounding some Blue Dye with Stone.
By surrounding either a Bucket of Water or a Bucket of Lava with Stone, you get a pair of opposing blocks that look purely elemental.
If opposing elements isn't your fantasy, then how about the divine struggle? Surrounding a Feather with Stone gets you Holystone, while surrounding some Coal gets you Grimstone.
Beyond this mortal plane is the Void. Surrounding an Ender Pearl with Obsidian and Stone nets you this fantastically mesmerizing block.

quests.name: A Custom Road
quests.description: Inside the home and inside the office aren't the only places you can Chisel your own artistic touch : how about outside on the road? Theres a lot of sidewalk and street designs, plus many signs you can make!

tasks.longDescription: By smelting Gravel, you can make Concrete. This is fantasic material for both walkways and roadways.
What is a proper road without proper lines? Mix some Redstone with some White Dye to make an eye-catching guide.
Surrounding a Sign with Stone lets you make an very noticeable warning sign!

quests.name: Improved Chisel Tools
quests.description: Your basic Iron Chisel is great and all, but it eventually wears out. Not to mention, if you are making a BIG construction, thats a whole lot of things you need to Chisel. By hand. My fingers hurt just thinking about it! Well, here's a set of advanced tools that should really help you out!

tasks.longDescription: The Diamond Chisel has a few distinct advantages. One, it lasts longer, thats for sure. Two, you can change Modes on it to Chisel larger amounts of placed blocks at once!
The Auto Chisel does what it says on the tin. You can place a Chisel into it, a basic material, and the Chiseled variation you want, and it'll slowly, steadily Chisel them for you!
The Speed Upgrade speeds up how fast the Auto Chisel works.
Normally, the Auto Chisel does not allow you to pipe or transport items into or out of it via pipe or other method. That is, unless you have the Automation upgrade.
Why Chisel things one at a time? The Stack Upgrade makes the Auto Chisel work on entire stacks of materials at once!

quests.name: A Custom Workplace
quests.description: How truely efficient is a workplace if it doesn't look and feel like a fantastic place to spend a third of your day in? Not that efficient, I'd say! If your workplace looks like every other concrete and wood, cookie cutter box, then how can you put 100% effort into your job? Well, you can Chisel your way to a nicer work environment!

tasks.longDescription: Laboratories are well known for their pristine, uniform walls that are easy to clean and maintain. Surrounding some Quartz with Stone will give us this clean look.
Looking for something less futuristic and a little more modern? Combining Stone and Iron nets you a Technical look, complete with giant fans, wires, and more.
Switching a bit of Stone for Glass, you can make some Technical blocks with transparency in them.
If you want to go back a bit to the rise of Industry, look no further than the Factory block. A little less Stone, and you have more rustic looking metal parts!
Surrounding Redstone with Stone gets you a much more Futuristic set of blocks.
For that futuristic Armored look, the Tyrian block gives you lots of options. Just surround an Iron Bar with Stone.
Another Futuristic look is to go Hexagonal. By surrounding a Coal Block with Stone, you get Hex Plating that looks amazingly futuristic.

Need to light an area to see in, but not, you know...ACTUALLY light it? Well, surround some Glowstone Dust with Stone and you'll get an Anti Block. It illuminates very brightly...but only itself. If you put it in a pitch black room, you can see only it clearly...and anything else that walks between you and it. You could probably use this for a greenscreen!

quests.name: Armourer's Workshop
quests.description: Designing your home, designing your work, designing your games...what is left? Well, designing your wardrobe of course! And not just as a fashion statement, but as a way to protect yourself! What if you could make a spectacular, fancy hat that also doubled as a pair of magic goggles? Or a posh, frilly dress that also blocked zombie bites? Or how about a paper fan that was actually a razor sharp sword? The possibilities, as always, are endless! But we have to start somewhere...and that somewhere is called the Equipment Cube. This will allow you to make designs that 'replace' the look of many of your armor and weapons. It won't work on ALL armor and weapons...but a lot of them! Heck, you can even change the look of your Arrows and even Blocks!

tasks.longDescription: This is the Equipment Cube. You'll need a lot of them, but they'll be reusable for each project.

quests.name: A Better Forge
quests.description: Now that we have some basic Equipment Cubes, we'll need a 'forge' to use them in. And by forge, I don't mean a hot smelter and an anvil. No, this is much more fashionable! You'll be crafting this armor yourself, as if you were building a house. Don't look at me like that, you'll understand soon! You'll need a nice big area, I'd say at least 50x50x50 blocks big. And a ton of Equipment Cubes, you cannot use any other material in your designs, sorry!

tasks.longDescription: When you place this down, be ready for a BIG surprise! Okay, now that the shock is over, you can see, well, your own head on an epic scale! This way, you can hand-craft the look of your armor and weapons as if you were constructing a building. You can select the different parts of the body you want to design for.

You will need somewhere to save your design, which we call a Skin. The Skin Template can be placed in the Armourer, a name typed in, and when you are done building with Equipment Cubes, you can save the design to the Template. You can now Wear your design! You'll probably have to rebind your Armor Skin screen though...I suggest the Minus key!
The Equipment Library is where you can save and load Skins from your hard drive (or the server you are playing on). There are some basic Skins already available for you to chose from!

While one way of applying skins is your Skin Equipment menu, sometimes you want a skin to be specific to a piece of armor. The Skinning Table allows you to apply a Skin to some pieces of equipment. Then when you or anyone uses it, it will have the skin instead!                  To remove the Skin from the equipment, combine it with Soap in your Skinning Table.

quests.name: Expanded Materials
quests.description: Basic Equipment Cubes are only the start! You can design your Skins with transparent Equipment Cubes as well! Not only that, how about glowing versions? Fabulous!

quests.name: In Living Color
quests.description: On their own, Equipment Cubes give shape to your Armor and Weapon designs...but are kind of boring. They are a single, uniform color, which is where all these tools come in!

tasks.longDescription: To apply color, you're going to need some brushes to start with. The basic Paint Brush will color one Equipment Cube at a time, while the Paint Roller will cover a 3x3x1 area.

To get the Color you want, you'll need a Colour Mixer. You can adjust the color setting in it, then place either a Paint Brush or Paint Roller in the top right slot to apply it. You can also hold one of these Brushes and Sneak + Right Click it on the Colour Mixer itself to copy the color.
You can Right Click this Colour Picker to copy the color on any Equipment Cube. You can then either place it, or Sneak + Right Click it, on a Colour Mixer to copy the colour to it.
Each of these tools can be used to add various color enhancements to your Equipment Cubes. You can Sneak + Right Click each one to set the Intensity of its function.

You may have noticed in the Colour Mixer, that you can choose the Type of Dye, between Normal, Dye 1 through 8, and None. When you are creating a Skin, you can apply a Type to a tool, and if it is a Dye #, you will see Dots on the Equipment Cubes.                              This will let you set your Skins to have different Dyeable sections. When you create a Skin, you can designate some or all the blocks to be dyeable. If you made a sword, you could make the Handle Dye 1, Blade Dye 2, and decorations Dye 3.     You will then need to fill Dye Bottles with the colors you want, and bring the Bottles and Skin to the Dye Table, where you can see how the dyed colors look before accepting it.

quests.name: A Fine Display
quests.description: You know, you can make all kinds of Skins...but you can only wear one set at a time! Just stashing them in a box doesn't seem right, so how about making a Mannequin for them? You can pose it and place any Skin Templates on it to customize it. You can even have it mimic someone's clothing by putting their name on a Name Tag in an Anvil, and then Right Clicking the Tag onto the Mannequin.

tasks.description: Did it Turn to Look at Me?!

quests.name: Tons of Toys
quests.description: Toys are fun to look at, fun to collect, and tend to keep the little ones busy and out of your hair...at least until they break the toy. These, at least, are quire sturdy!

quests.name: Big Business
quests.description: Eye catching displays and tools of the trade are standard fare for businesses. What better way to show people what you sell than a big sign?

quests.name: Worldly Wonders
quests.description: The world is a great big place, full of interesting things. Why not make some of them to show them off?

quests.name: Festive Fun
quests.description: Holidays and celebrations are a great time and a perfect excuse to go all out with decorations!

quests.name: Iron Chest
quests.description: A quite standard set of storage methods we like to employ are simple Chests. We make them with various materials, allowing us to make them bigger and better, able to store all of your goods! The first Chest, though, is not of Iron, but...of Dirt. The most amazing Chest of all, able to fulfill all your inventory needs!

tasks.longDescription: Only kidding, this is a little joke Engineer Erin likes to play on new Assistants. I, as a Stockmaster, must uphold this tradition. The Dirt Chest holds only one stack of items. Not much...but still amusing.

quests.name: Of Copper and Iron
quests.description: Jokes aside, Wooden Chests are quite servicable in their own right, but quickly become cramped and full. Even Double Chests fill up quite fast, and with you all alone, I figure you'll be storing everything you can to survive. Given that, the first two chests I will show you are an excellent start in improving your storage capacity.

tasks.longDescription: The Copper Chest has a little more room in it than a basic Wooden Chest.
The Iron Chest has the same amount of room a Double Wooden Chest does.

quests.name: Of Silver and Gold
quests.description: Now that you've doubled the capacity of a single Wooden Chest, it's time to expand even further. By taking more precious metals such as Silver and Gold, we can increase the space in each Chest even more!

tasks.longDescription: Silver is a very pretty material, and it also makes excellent chests.
Not only does it have more storage space than Silver, it's also a great way to display your wealth!

quests.name: Of Diamond, Crystal, and Dark
quests.description: Going beyond the precious metals, we can look to perfecting the structure of the Chest itself to maximize our Storage potential. What better way than with Diamonds and Glass? And perhaps, some other, less obvious ways?

tasks.longDescription: While fairly expensive, for the price, you get a lot of bang for your buck. With the most storage space in it of the Iron Chest line, you'll be hard pressed to fill a bunch of these. Or will you? It always seems like there is never enough room.
Ever wanted to see what was in a Diamond Chest without, you know, opening it? Well, with a bit of glass, you can do just that!

If your normal Diamond Chests seem a bit too...fragile, you can use the strength of Obsidian to fortify one! It'll withstand some pretty strong blasts, but don't skimp on the insurance if you're playing with Nukes...

quests.name: Uprading Success
quests.description: The beauty of the Iron Chest system is that it enables you to upgrade chests without having to empty them and pick them back up. By crafting an Upgrade instead of the next chest up, you can Sneak + Right Click the upgrade on the appropriate chest to...well...upgrade it!

quests.name: Open Modular Turrets
quests.description: Finding a place to store all your belongings is easy. Defending it when all sorts of terrors of the night want your brains? Well, thats a bit more difficult. Theres a lot of ways to defend yourself and fight the creatures of the dark, but there is only one of you, and hundreds of them.                           What you need...is superior firepower. Something that can be adjusted to fit the needs of your growing base. For military and defense applications, The Ferret Business prefers to employ Open Modular Turrets. As long as you supply enough RF Energy and Ammo, they will defend your belongings tirelessly. With a wide variety of options, you can surely find something that will meet your defense needs!                               These consist of Bases that can be supplied Ammo and RF Energy, and Turrets that you can attatch to any side. The Turret Bases can be accessed by Right Clicking them with an open hand. If you Right Click them with any simple block, you will disguise the Turret Base.

tasks.longDescription: Most Bases are made with Sensors, which are used to identify targets. Most turrets have a Barrel and Chamber as well as a Sensor, so that each one can target different enemies at once.        The Wooden Turret Base can only be powered by the Basic Turret Base Crank. Any other side that is not being powered (whether by a crank or by some other RF Energy pipe) can have a Turret on it.                                                To attatch the crank to the Turret Base, you will need to Sneak + Right Click the Crank onto the Base.
The Disposable Item Turret  will fire ANY item you put into the Wooden Base ammo pool. Due to the high energy and velocity items are shot at, they will be destroyed.
For a little more oomph in your shots, you can use a Potato Launcher Turret. Instead of consuming any junk laying around, it is specially formed to fire nothing but Potatoes.

quests.name: Expansion Perfection
quests.description: Seldom will you use all six sides of a Turret Base. You'll use at least one for Power, one as a connection point to the floor or wall, and a handful of Turrets.           The use of Expanders on these unused sides allows you to increase the Ammo Storage and RF Energy Storage of a Turret Base.       Inventory Expanders add 9 more slots of Inventory, but the limit of Stack Size depends on the Tier of Expander.

tasks.longDescription: Expanded Inventory max stack size is 4.
Expanded Inventory max stack size is 8.
Expanded Inventory max stack size is 16.
Expanded Inventory max stack size is 32.
Expanded Inventory max stack size is 64.

quests.name: Upgrading Potential
quests.description: All Turret Bases beyond the Wooden one can be augmented in various ways. One way is to add an Upgrade or two to them. These usually increase one of the stats of the connected Turrets, whether it increase their range or decrease how much power each shot takes.                                    All Upgrades can be stacked multiple times.

tasks.longDescription: The Accuracy upgrade will increase each turret's accuracy by 20%.
The Efficiency Upgrade will decrease how much RF every shot will take by 8% per Upgrade.
Fire Rate Upgrade will increase how fast your turrets fire by 10% per upgrade.
Each Range Upgrade will add 2 more blocks of range to your Turrets.
Scattershot adds two projectiles per shot and takes two more ammo each shot as well. The turret's acuracy is decreased as well, and it takes more RF Energy to fire.

quests.name: Additional Power
quests.description: Addons are a bit more costly than Upgrades, but do fairly different things. Generally, each base can only take one Addon until you get to the top Tier Resonant Base.

tasks.longDescription: The Damage Boost Addon will add 2 damage to every shot.
The Solar Addon will allow your Turret Base to generate RF Energy if it is out in the sunlight.
The Redstone Reactor will allow your Turret to consume Redstone Dust to generate power.
The Turret Concealer Addon will allow your Turrets to hide in their base when not targetting an enemy.
The Recycle addon gives your Turrets a small chance of not only consuming no ammo each shot, but also generating more.

You can add a Serial Port to your Turret Base, which will make it compatable with Open Computers and ComputerCraft. How to use this functionality I'm not sure, but there should be some sort of manual I would hope.

Technological advances aren't the only thing your Turrets can use for power. The Essentia Converter will take Thaumcraft Essentia and use it like RF Energy to power the Turret.                        Ordo Essentia provides 10x boost in power.

quests.name: Tier 3 - Boom and Doom
quests.description: Now, a hail of bullets are good for smaller monsters, but you seem to have some much bigger fish that want to fry you. Bigger firepower requires bigger power reserves though, so you'll need a better Turret Base. This will also give you much better options in dealing with hostiles, ones that don't involve just shooting them...

tasks.longDescription: Better materials, better options!
The Tier 3 Base is Reinforced and provides more power and faster power transfer to turrets.

The Grenade Launcher will launch... bare with me now... Grenades. These grenades will not damage your home, they are specially formulated to damage any creature... and this includes you and your Assistants, keep in mind. They will hit a large area, but the cavaet is that they take a few seconds to prime and explode after landing.

The Realitivistic Turret won't shoot projectiles at your targets... instead, it will highlight them for you with a cloudy effect. It may also make them weaker, but this is a brand new turret and does not have a manual yet.

quests.name: Tier 4 - Whoosh and Fwoosh
quests.description: If rolling grenades and waiting for fuses isn't your thing, but big explosions are, then the next Tier up is exactly what you are looking for!

tasks.longDescription: Diamonds and Quartz add even more power and ability to the Turret designs
Even more power storage for your turrets.
The Rocket Launcher Turret is one of the most accurate Turrets but it fires somewhat slowly.
The Teleporter Turret doesn't attack enemies directly. Instead it will teleport them to the Turret, allowing you to do more than just kill them.

quests.name: Tier 5 - Zap Pow
quests.description: If the lower Tiers are just not enough Firepower, say if you were assaulting some Deep, Dark fortress of hostility, then you'll need every shot to hit like a Mach Truck. I have not one, but TWO Turrets that can help you out here. Keep in mind, though, that with great Power comes great Power Consumption.

tasks.longDescription: To withstand the sheer power of these weapons, you'll need better components.
The Resonant Base is the only base that can have two Upgrades AND two addons.
The Rail Gun Turret is the slowest firing Turret, but every shot hits hard and precise.
If you are tired of mass producing Ammo for your Turrets and have a ton of spare RF Energy, why not invest in a Laser Turret?

quests.name: Redeem Enderium Chit
quests.description: Fulfilling Contracts succesfully earns you Trader Chits. By combining two of the same value, you get a larger chit.                 The larger the chit you redeem, the more value it has. Four Bronze[8] chits are worth less than a single Silver[32] chit. Four Silver[32] chits are worth less than a single Thaumium[128] chit, and so on.

quests.name: Piecing It Together
quests.description: Okay, you got the Enlarger and Shrinker, right? Now we'll need to put them into a larger device before they are useable. What, you expected to just slap the module like a sticker on something and POOF, smaller! Course not, it'd shrink and then you'd need a magnifying glass to even see it! Then you'd also need a pair of tweezers, and a tiny tiny Enlarging Module to make it normal size again, and shoes just in case you did drop a few shrunken machines in the carpet...mechanical caltrops, thats what we'd call them!

tasks.longDescription: This panel lets the Compact Machine shrink and expand whatever passes through it.
By building a block of Interfaces around a Diamond, you create the basis of the Compact Machine. This lets you pipe in power, liquid, and items in and out of every side of the Compact Machine.

quests.name: Is So Tiny!
quests.description: Your Compact Machine is almost complete, don't worry! Now you just need to build a case for it. Lots of materials work fine, but we'll start with the cheapest : wooden planks! I know, for a machine it seems an odd choice, but wood tends to go in and out of style for some reason, even for machines. Wood and the World Resizing Cube will make the tiniest Compact Machine you can ge, but even that  provides you a lot of space! To enter and exit it, though, you'll need a special tool...

tasks.longDescription: Inside this Machine is its own miniaturized space. You can place it in your base, and each side can have RF Power, Items, and Fluids pumped in and out them.

To enter and leave a Compact Machine, you'll need your own Personal Shrinking Device. Craft it, and then Right Click it onto the Machine itself to enter it. Now you are inside the Compact Machine! Any items you bring into it are shrunk with you, and this includes other Machines so you can place it inside!

quests.name: Extra Tools
quests.description: Now that you can enter and exit your own Compact Machines, theres a few extra things you may like. Notice the walls inside your Machine? If you like that look, you can make it for your own constructions! The other item, though, is less form and all function! With the Quantum Entangler, you can 'attatch' two machines in different locations to the same Compact Machine space.

tasks.longDescription: To Entangle two machines together, they have to fit a few criteria:           1) They have to be the same              size.                                    2) You must have Right Clicked a         Nether Star onto each                 Machine.                                3) The second machine must               not have been entered yet!       Then you may Right Click the Quantum Entangler onto the first machine whose space you want to link, then onto the second Machine. They will now lead to the same place, and anything you pipe through the Interfaces can be accessed by either Machine.

quests.name: Growing Larger
quests.description: Now you know how to make Compact Machines. Each side of the Machine on the outside corresponds to an Interface on the inside. By using something like Conduits or Pipes or Ducts, you can transfer things like Power in and out of the machine. Each Compact Machine tier is just a bit larger than the previous tier.

quests.name: Mine's Bigger!
quests.description: We can keep making these bigger and bigger! All sorts of things you can fit into a Compact Machine with enough space. A whole smeltery? Yep! How about a small factory? Definitely! Got something dangerous? Well, stuff it into a Compact Machine!

quests.name: Maximum Size!
quests.description: The Nether Star enables us to go one step further than we could before, which is crazy! Before, a case of Diamond made the largest space available, but now Nether Stars push our miniaturizing ability even further!

quests.name: JABBA
quests.description: Here at The Ferret Business, we stockpile lots and lots of the same thing. Hundreds of gemstones. Thousands of metal ingots. All manner of electonic components. Now, placing them into lots of chests and storage boxes is all well and good, but it wastes their potential of holding more than one kind of item. Plus, even the largest chest has a limit, and you can also accidently place the wrong item into it. This is where Barrels come in. JABBA Barrels, that is! Each one holds only one kind of item, but can be upgraded and customized in so many different ways!

tasks.longDescription: After placing the Barrel, you can add an item by Right Clicking it onto the Barrel. Now only THAT item can be put into the Barrel.                     You can add all of a held item into a Barrel by Double Right Clicking.                                        To remove a stack of items, Left Click. To remove a single one, Sneak when Left Clicking.                           You can lock or unlock a Barrel to an item by Sneak + Right Clicking it with an empty hand. This makes it so you can empty the Barrel, but it will still only accept that item.

quests.name: Power Provider - Tier 2
quests.description: The Tier 2 Ferret Battery will earn you 25 coins.

tasks.longDescription: Put a Tier 1 Ferret Battery into your EnderIO Alloy Smelter, and provide 24 Million RF to charge it to Tier 2.

quests.name: Power Provider - Tier 4
quests.description: A Tier 4 Ferret Battery will earn you 500 Coins.

tasks.longDescription: Take a Tier 3 Ferret Battery and place it in an EnderIO Alloy Smelter and provide 400 Million RF to charge it to Tier 4.

quests.name: Home Deco Supply - Inexpensive
quests.description: Better materials make household items that last longer and look better.

tasks.longDescription: To fill an Inexpensive Home Deco Crate, you will need to combine any 6 Inexpensive Home Decorations and an Unfilled Shipping Crate.

quests.name: Thematic Supply - Inexpensive
quests.description: Fancier, more intricate Thematic Decorations require more time and better materials to create.

tasks.longDescription: To fill an Inexpensive Thematic Deco Crate, you will need to combine any 6 Inexpensive Thematic Decorations and an Unfilled Shipping Crate.

quests.name: Very Cheap Home Deco x25
quests.description: This Contract is for 25 Very Cheap Home Deco Supply Crates.

quests.name: Cheap Toy Supply Crate x25
quests.description: This Contract is for 25 Cheap Toy Supply Crates.

quests.name: Very Cheap Job Deco x25
quests.description: This Contract is for 25 Very Cheap Job Deco Supply Crates.

quests.name: Cheap Thematic Deco Supply x25
quests.description: This Contract is for 25 Cheap Thematic Deco Supply Crates.

tasks.longDescription: A task where the player can hand in items or fluids. One can also use the Quest Delivery System to submit items and fluids.

quests.name: Cheap Home Deco Crate x25
quests.description: This Contract is for 25 Cheap Home Deco Supply Crates.

quests.name: Awakened Weapons
quests.description: The sheer power of Awakened Draconium can be harnessed in many ways, but one that should definitely benefit you would be to have it forged into powerful weapons.

quests.name: Tools of the Wyvern
quests.description: Draconium is a fantastic material, able to tap into and utilize so much potential power and magic. Hopefully we can unlock its secrets, and it will guide us to getting you out of there, and open up even more doors for all of us.        Shaping it into Cores was an excellent first step, and we've been able to expand upon it. You can make more powerful Cores of varying types just by combining a few together with other powerful materials.
